PLH - Content - Positive - CheckIn - Onl.message_text:
That is okay! Here is a list of some of the risks and dangers that you may encounter online:
• Adults targeting people for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
• Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography
• Sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos.
• Cyberbullying from other people and strangers.

Sorry to hear that you are finding this challenging. Here is a review on quick technical fixes: 
• Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.
https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/
• Set up parental controls.
https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/
• Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.
 https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/social-media/
• Cover webcams when not in use.

The idea of talking to children about abuse can be scary. We don't know what to say. But there are some simple things that can help them understand when it is not OK to be touched, and that they can tell you if something ever happens.
When you are walking or doing something together it can be easier to chat.

Here are 3 things that you should make sure your child knows to protect them from abuse:

1. Learn about private parts
2. Your body belongs to you
3. Bad secrets should be told

Type "1" to "3" to learn more about these tips. Type "N" to stop this tip.

1. Learn about private parts

The parts of their body that go under people's underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.

2. Your body belongs to you

If someone tries to touch your children's private parts they must say NO and tell a grown up that they trust.

3. Bad secrets should be told. 

Your children should tell you if there is a secret that makes them feel worried. You will not be angry. Only nice secrets - like a surprise birthday party - should be kept secret.

Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to protect your child from abuse:

Here are 5 steps that you can do to help your children continue learning during this time:

1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork
2. Make learning fun and playful
3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher 
4. Stay connected with your child's school and teachers
5. Support your child when they return to school

Type "1" to "5" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.
@fields.child_nickname

Step 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork

Make a daily plan with @fields.child_nickname for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.

Step 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork

Make a daily plan with your child for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.
@fields.child_nickname

Step 2. Make learning fun and playful

Children learn best when learning is fun! Try to find ways to make learning playful to keep @fields.child_nickname interested and engaged. Type "Help" if you ever need any fun ideas!

Step 2. Make learning fun and playful

Children learn best when learning is fun! Try to find ways to make learning playful to keep your child interested and engaged. Type "Help" if you ever need any fun ideas!
@fields.child_nickname
@fields.gender_personalisation

Giving calm consequences help teach our children responsibility for what they do. They also allow discipline that is controlled. This is more effective than hitting or shouting. 

Here are 5 tips for using consequences:

1. Give a choice before consequence
2. Stay calm but be firm
3. Be realistic and follow through
4. Reconnect afterwards
5. Consequences for breaking rules

To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "5". You can also type "N" to move on.
@fields.child_nickname
1. Give @fields.child_nickname a choice to follow your instruction before giving them the consequence.
1. Give your child a choice to follow your instruction before giving them the consequence.

2. Try to stay calm but firm when giving the consequence.
If you start yelling, it will just make things worse. Take a deep breath before you speak in a clear, calm, and firm voice.

3. Be realistic and follow through
Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.
@fields.child_nickname

4. Reconnect afterwards. 
Once the consequence is over, give @fields.child_nickname a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.

4. Reconnect afterwards. 
Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.

5. Consequences for breaking rules
Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V.
@fields.child_nickname
For example, you can tell @fields.child_nickname that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.

When our children share something that is especially troubling, we need to remember to stay calm, listen, and be open.

Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:
• Take a deep breath before you respond. 
• Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.
• Notice how you feel. Ask yourself, "What does my child need right now?" 
• Reassure your child that you are there for them. 
• You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.
• Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action. 
• Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.

Parent: “What’s wrong, my dear? Come and sit by me and tell me what happened.” 

Child: “It’s that person…they touched me…”

(1)

Parent: “Take your time... I am listening.” 

Child: “… they held me down…told me I would be in trouble if I told anybody…”

(2)

Parent: “I believe you. You are not in trouble. It is not your fault. This is a big thing and we will find a way to get the help you need. I wonder where we can go for help…?”

Child: “The clinic? But could you come with me?”

(3)

Parent: “Yes, they will know what to do. Of course, I will come with you. Remember, this is not your fault. I love you and we will get through this.” 

Child: “Thanks so much.”

(4)

Here are 6 simple steps that you can do to support family harmony at home:

1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids
2. Keep it positive
3. Listen carefully to others
4. Share the load
5. Take care of yourself
6. Do nice things together as a family.

Type "1" to 6" to learn more about these tips. Type "N" to stop this tip.

Step 1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids

How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.

Bad communication between adults in the household can have a negative impact on our children. The more we practice modeling peaceful, loving relationships for our children, the more secure and loved they will feel.

Step 2. Use positive language. It works!

Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”
Praise others to make them feel appreciated and good about themselves. Simple words like, “Thank you for clearing the dinner,” or “Thank you for watching the baby” can make a big difference

Step 3. Be a great listener

Listen to others when they are talking with you. Be open and show them that you hear what they are saying. It can help to summarise what you have heard before responding: “What I hear you saying is…”

Step 4. Share the load

Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members

Step 5. Take care of yourself

Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household. It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break

Decide to take a break from arguing when you see arguments building up, and go into another room or outside if you can.

You can always type "Help" if you need an activity to help you with stress.

Step 6. Do nice things together as a family

Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity. Find ways to spend time alone with other adults in your home, too!

Here are some tips that might help when your baby cries:

1. Why babies cry
2. Respond as soon as you can
3. Check to see why your baby is crying
4. Comfort your baby
5. Take a break if you need it
6. Be gentle and patient with yourself
7. If you think your baby is injured or sick, call or visit a clinic

To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "7". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.

1. Why do babies cry?

Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!

2. Respond as soon as you can

Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.

3.  Check to see why your baby is crying

There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!
@fields.child_nickname

4. Comfort your baby

Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed @fields.child_nickname or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - @fields.child_nickname can actually sense tension from you, too!

4. Comfort your baby

Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed your baby or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - your baby can actually sense tension from you, too!
@fields.child_nickname

5. Take a break!

If you are getting angry because @fields.child_nickname won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Stay nearby so that you can monitor @fields.child_nickname. Check on @fields.child_nickname every 5-10 minutes.

5. Take a break!

If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Stay nearby so that you can monitor your baby. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.
Call someone for help - a family member, a friend. Sometimes just talking with someone is enough, but if you feel overwhelmed, ask someone for help. Calling for help is a sign of strength.

6. Be gentle and patient with yourself

I know this is not easy. You are not a bad father if your baby continues to cry after you have done all you can to calm them. You are doing your best!

Here are some tips for how we can help our children learn how to cope with their emotions:

1. Be open to your child
2. Share your own feelings
3. Help your child learn how to talk about feelings
4. Talking about difficult emotions
5. Notice the positive emotions
6. Show your child that you care

To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.

1. Be open to your child

Your child will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.

2. Share your own feelings

When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.

3. Help your child learn how to talk about feelings

There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

4. Talking about difficult emotions

It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.
But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.
@fields.child_nickname

5. Notice the positive emotions

Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help @fields.child_nickname be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

5. Notice the positive emotions

Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!
@fields.child_nickname

6. Show your child that you care

Use physical and verbal support to make @fields.child_nickname feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind @fields.child_nickname that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

6. Show your child that you care

Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind your child that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

Here are 6 steps on how we can reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like tantrums using what we call Ignore:

1. Try to redirect your child’s attention
2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore
3. Ignore the behaviour not your child
4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour
5. Be consistent when ignoring
6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times.

To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to move on.

1. Try to redirect your child's attention

When they start demanding for something or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity. Praise them for that positive behaviour!

2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore

These are behaviours like whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child. But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!
If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way.
@fields.child_nickname

For example, if @fields.child_nickname whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to @fields.child_nickname when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!
For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!
@fields.child_nickname

3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.

Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what @fields.child_nickname is doing.

3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.

Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what your child is doing.
When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.
This takes time AND patience. Normally your child will try to test you and behave worse. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.
@fields.child_nickname

4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour

Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give @fields.child_nickname plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.

4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour

Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.
@fields.child_nickname

At this time, it is more important that you involve @fields.child_nickname in a positive activity instead of talking about what just happened. You can do that later like at night or the next day. Right now @fields.child_nickname needs love.

At this time, it is more important that you involve your child in a positive activity instead of talking about what just happened. You can do that later like at night or the next day. Right now your child needs love.

5. Be consistent when ignoring

Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.
Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.
@fields.child_nickname
Try to remain consistent. Over time, @fields.child_nickname will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.
Try to remain consistent. Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.

6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times

Children need attention. If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.

If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, it is either because you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!

2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore
3. Ignore the behaviour not your child
4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour
5. Be consistent when ignoring
6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times

You can also type "N" to move on.

Challenges are stressful. But problem-solving can really help. There are 6 basic steps for problem solving:

1. Identify the problem
2. Think of possible solutions
3. Figure out what the results of each solution would be
4. Choose one solution 
5. Try it out!
6. Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution

Here are 5 tips that can help you keep yourself safe online:

1. Learn about the risks and dangers
2. Quick tech fixes
3. Create healthy and safe online habits
4. Maintain privacy
5. Report and seek help

To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "5". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.

1. Learn about risks and dangers

• Adults targeting people for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
• Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography
• Sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos.
• Cyberbullying from other people and strangers.

2. Quick tech fixes

• Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.
https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/
• Set up parental controls.
https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/
• Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.
 https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/social-media/
• Cover webcams when not in use.

3. Create healthy and safe online habits

You can also create healthy and safe online habits like creating device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).

4. Maintain privacy

Keep personal information private, especially from strangers. – some people are not who they say they are!
Remember that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).

5. Report and seek help

Report to SAFERKIDSPH and BANTAYBATA163 to get support if you or your children experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.

SAFERKIDSPH: https://www.saferkidsph.org/

BANTAYBATA163: https://corporate.abs-cbn.com/lingkodkapamilya/bantay-bata/about

PNP Aling Pulis
http://wcpc.pnp.gov.ph/index.php/about-wcpc/contact-information

UP-PGH Child Protection Unit
https://cpu.upm.edu.ph/node/17

5. Making actions and links

@fields.child_nickname

6. Talking about feelings
Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about @fields.child_nickname’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.

6. Talking about feelings
Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.

Here are some examples! 
“Look, she is smiling. Why do you think she is smiling? What made you smile today?”
“The monkey is sad because he is all on his own. Can you remember when you were last sad?”
“That tiger looks angry. Why do you think he is angry? Do you remember when I got angry this morning?”

7. Babies and Books!
Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning. And it is okay for them to put the book in their mouth - they are exploring!

Making a budget.
A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget can help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.

• Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.

• Write next to each picture how much each thing costs.
• Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

PLH - Internal - Update incomplete toolkits
@fields.from_theme

Create routines! Your children will feel more secure and safe when they know what is expected of them and how each day will go. Make a plan with them with time for play, meals, chores, school, and sleep.
@fields.type_of_media
Here's a video to help you create daily routines with your children.
Here's an audio message to help you create daily routines with your children.
Daily routines, such as time for schoolwork, play, meals, and sleep, can help our children feel safe and secure. They also give our children a sense of security.
PLH - Internal - Update toolkits
Would you like to learn more about this tip?
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to receive more tips about how to manage your child's behaviour.

Here are 4 simple tips that you can use when establishing routines with your children: 

1. Give one instruction at a time
2. Use transition warnings to help move from one activity to the next one
3. Create regular eating and sleeping times
4. Involve your child in creating daily routines

To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to 4". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
1. Help your younger children learn routines by taking them through the activity step by step. Give one instruction at a time. Praise them each time they follow!
2. Transition warnings can also be very helpful. They give your child some time to prepare for the next activity: "In 5 minutes it will be time to pack up the toys before bedtime…"
3. Regular eating and sleeping times are especially important for babies. Not enough sleep can make your child cranky, irritable, and short tempered.

Here are some tips for how to help your child prepare for bedtime:

• Try to have regular bedtimes each day as much as possible.
• Try to make it quiet and the lights in the room dim. 
• Spend some time with your child. You can sing a lullaby or tell a calm story.
• Give your child a hug and kiss goodnight before leaving the room.
@fields.child_nickname
4. Involve @fields.child_nickname in creating daily plans. Set goals and rewards together. Let them plan when they do schoolwork and when they can relax!

Here are 6 tips that can help you keep your children safe online:

1. Learn about the risks and dangers
2. Quick tech fixes
3. Create healthy and safe online habits
4. Spend time with your child online
5. Build open communication
6. Report and seek help

To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.

1. Learn about risks and dangers

• Adults targeting children for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
• Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography
• Teens sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos of themselves.
• Cyberbullying from other young people and strangers.
This does not mean we should ban our children from spending time online. It just means that we need to learn how to protect them in a new world.

2. Tech fixes to protect your children online

• Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.
https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/
• Set up parental controls.
https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/
• Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.
 https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/social-media/
• Cover webcams when not in use.
@fields.child_nickname

3. Create healthy and safe online habits

Involve @fields.child_nickname in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.
Create device-free spaces and times in your house
(eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).

Child tech agreement: https://www.esafety.gov.au/sites/default/files/2020-01/Our%20Family%20Tech%20Agreement_0.pdf
Teen tech agreement: https://www.childnet.com/ufiles/Family-Agreement.pdf

https://www.saferkidsph.org/stay-safe-online/

3. Create healthy and safe online habits

Involve your child or teen in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.
Create device-free spaces and times in your house
(eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).

Child tech agreement: https://www.esafety.gov.au/sites/default/files/2020-01/Our%20Family%20Tech%20Agreement_0.pdf
Teen tech agreement: https://www.childnet.com/ufiles/Family-Agreement.pdf

https://www.saferkidsph.org/stay-safe-online/
@fields.child_nickname

Help @fields.child_nickname learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers – some people are not who they say they are!
Remind your children that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).
 Actively supervise children’s time online, including computers, smartphones, and tablets.

Help your child learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers – some people are not who they say they are!
Remind your children that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).

@fields.child_nickname

4. Spend time with your child or teen online

Get to know how @fields.child_nickname experiences the digital world.
Explore websites, social media, games, and apps together.
Talk to your teen on how to report things that aren't OK.

Common Sense Media and SaferKidsPH have great advice for apps, games and entertainment for different ages.

https://www.commonsensemedia.org/app-reviews

https://www.saferkidsph.org/stay-safe-online/

4. Spend time with your child or teen online

Get to know how your child experiences the digital world.
Explore websites, social media, games, and apps together.
Talk to your teen on how to report things that aren't OK.

Common Sense Media and SaferKidsPH have great advice for apps, games and entertainment for different ages.

https://www.commonsensemedia.org/app-reviews

https://www.saferkidsph.org/stay-safe-online/

5. Build open communication and trusting relationships

Tell your children that if they experience something online (or anywhere) that makes them feel upset, uncomfortable, or scared, they can talk to you and you will not get mad or punish them.

6. Report and seek help

Report to SAFERKIDSPH and BANTAYBATA163 to get support if you or your children experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.

SAFERKIDSPH: https://www.saferkidsph.org/

BANTAYBATA163: https://corporate.abs-cbn.com/lingkodkapamilya/bantay-bata/about

PNP Aling Pulis
http://wcpc.pnp.gov.ph/index.php/about-wcpc/contact-information

UP-PGH Child Protection Unit
https://cpu.upm.edu.ph/node/17

Here is a comic on discussing online activities with your child

Parent: "Jen, have you done your homework?"

Child: "Just a minute, I'm finishing this tiktok video"

(1)

Parent: "You are a really great dancer! Tell me about why you like it."

Child: "All my friends are on it. I have more than 600 likes and 120 followers."

Parent: "I’m proud of how well you dance, Jen. But we need to make sure you are safe on this. I know your friends look at TikTok, but with an open account there are also paedophiles who look at videos of teenagers. Paedophiles are older people who want to attack young children and teens."

(2)

Parent: "Let’s look together online at how we can keep this fun for you but also safe. Look – you can make your account private and control who follows you. So you can accept people you know but not strangers. Can we make a rule together that you can use TikTok but with a private account? I trust you to know who to accept!"

(3)

Parent: "I’m proud of you Jen..."

(4)

Here are 4 steps to help you get your children to follow your instructions more often:

1. Get their attention
2. Be positive, specific, and realistic
3. One instruction at a time
4. Praise them for doing it! 

To learn more about one of these steps, type "1" to "4". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
@fields.child_nickname

Step 1. Get Your Child's Attention
Look at @fields.child_nickname and say their name when you give your child an instruction. Get down to their level.

Step 1. Get Your Child's Attention
Look at your child and say their name when you give your child an instruction. Get down to their level.
@fields.child_nickname

Step 2. Be Specific, Positive, and Realistic!
Describe exactly what you want @fields.child_nickname to do. Say, 'Please wash your hands for 20 seconds before coming to dinner, instead of 'Wash your hands.'

Step 2. Be Specific, Positive, and Realistic!

@fields.child_nickname
Use positive words when telling @fields.child_nickname what to do. Say, ‘Please put your clothes away in the cupboard,’ instead of ‘Don’t make a mess’.
Use positive words when telling your child what to do. Say, ‘Please put your clothes away in the cupboard,’ instead of ‘Don’t make a mess’.
Can your child actually do what you are asking them? It is very hard for a child to keep quiet inside for a whole day but maybe they can keep quiet for 15 minutes.

Step 3. Give Instructions One at a Time
Children are much more likely to do what you ask if you break things up into smaller steps.

Step 4. Praise Your Children When They Follow Instructions
They will feel good about it and be more likely to follow instructions in the future!

PLH - Internal - Update incomplete toolkits
@fields.from_theme
Household rules can help keep our children safe from potential dangers both inside the house and in the community. They also help children to know what kind of behaviour is expected from them.
@fields.type_of_media
Here's is a video on how you can involve your children in establishing household rules.
Here's an audio message on how you can involve your children in establishing household rules.

Here are some simple tips on how you can make household rules with your children and teens: 

• Involve your child in establishing household rules.
• Make your household rules clear and specific.
• Make sure your child understands the reasons why you are establishing a household rule.
• Make your household rules fair and realistic (just like instructions).
• Praise and simple incentives can help support your child in following a household rule.
• Add only 1 household rule at a time.
Children and teens are spending a lot more time online. Here is a comic on how you can create safe and healthy online habits like scheduling time online and offline.

Parent: “Juan, you have been spending a lot of time on your tablet. Why do you think I am concerned about that?” 

Child: “Um…because I am not doing my schoolwork?” 

(1)

Parent: “Yes, that is one reason. It is important that you make the time for your schoolwork. I also like seeing you being more active. Maybe we can make a household rule about gadget use. What do you think would be a fair limit each day?” 

Child: “Um…two hours a day?”

(2)

Parent: “Hmmm…I think that might be too much time. You have so much else to do every day.” 

Child: “How about one hour for fun and one hour for learning?

(3)

Parent: “That sounds reasonable. I would also like you to do your schoolwork before using any gadgets. So from now on, the household rule is that you do your schoolwork before using gadgets and that you can have 1 hour for free time and 1 hour for educational activities. Okay?” 

Child: “Okay.”

(4)

Step 1: What are important places in our community?

• Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.
• Draw a map of your child or teen’s community, with pictures of all the main places like streets, your house, school, shops, places your teen visits...

• Discuss which areas on your map are unsafe for teenagers – CROSS those off.

Step 2:  Which places are safe and unsafe?

@fields.child_nickname

Step 3: Where can you get support?

• Sometimes, we can find ourselves in trouble.
• Discuss together where you and @fields.child_nickname can get support or help when you face a crisis – MARK those areas with a little object like a stone or piece of paper. 
• Some helpful places may include home, school, police station, clinic.

Step 3: Where can you get support?

Step 4: Online map

• Draw pictures of the apps and websites they use
• Praise your child for how good they are at using the web!
• Talk about which ones might be unsafe. Why?
• Are there plans you could make together to make using the internet safer for your child and their friends?
• It can really help for parents to learn about this in advance.
